head.headtext: Proof of a negative or affirmative defense

para.paratext: “If a negation or negative affirmation is essential to a party's case or defense, the proof of such negation or negative affirmation lies on the party so affirming it.”[1] The party has the burden of persuasion as to the negative.[2] He also has the burden of producing evidence, but, where the evidence involves proof of a negative, only slight evidence will shift the burden of producing evidence, especially where the other party has the greatest opportunity of factual knowledge.[3]

A defendant does not plead an affirmative defense simply by denying the allegations of the plaintiff even when such denial contains affirmative statements.[4] However, if the defendant pleads an affirmative defense or seeks affirmative relief, he has both the burden of persuasion and the burden of producing evidence on these issues.[5] A defendant moving for summary judgment on this basis of an affirmative defense “may not rely upon an absence of evidence in the record disproving the affirmative defense but must carry the burden of affirmatively proving the defense.”[6] However, the nonmoving party does not have an obligation to argue to the trial court that the movant has not met its burden of proof.[7] Usually, in pleading his affirmative defense, a defendant will admit a prima facie case for the plaintiff and thus carry the plaintiff's burdens for him.[8]
O.C.G.A. § 9-11-8(c) sets out a number of specific affirmative defenses in civil actions. The list in this section is not exclusive,[9] but the exact nature of an affirmative defense is not clear.

In Eidson v. Mathews,[10] plaintiff sought to recover for damages and injuries received in a collision between two automobiles, one of which was driven by the defendant's testate. The defendant contended that the deceased had a stroke immediately prior to the collision. The trial judge charged the jury that this was an affirmative defense and that the defendant had the “burden of proof” to show that the deceased had a stroke immediately prior to the collision so that the collision was an act of God. The Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the decision, but dissenting Judge Hall stated that this was not an affirmative defense within the meaning of O.C.G.A. § 9-11-8(c) and suggested that the majority had confused the “burden of persuasion” with the “burden of producing evidence.”

The same problem arose in Nash v. Hess Oil & Chemical Corp.[11] where the plaintiff's husband was shot by an attendant at one of the defendant's service stations. The plaintiff alleged that the shooting was willful and deliberate. The defendant denied the allegations and relied on justification although no plea of justification was filed. The trial judge charged the jury that the plaintiff must prove that the shooting was without justification in order to recover. The Georgia Court of Appeals approved the charge, noting that the plaintiff's complaint alleged that the defendant acted “willfully and deliberately,” that the defendants' answers denied the allegation, and that defendant did not file a plea of justification. The court also noted that justification was not included in the statutory list of affirmative defenses, O.C.G.A. § 9-11-8(c). The burden was therefore upon the plaintiff to prove the shooting was unprovoked as alleged in her complaint.
Likewise, a student bears the burden of proof in a disciplinary hearing where the student raised self-defense as her justification for her conduct.[12]

Clearly, “act of God”[13] and justification[14] are now both recognized affirmative defenses though not listed in O.C.G.A. § 9-11-8(c). Likewise, the defense of sovereign immunity of a state agency raises the issue of the trial court's subject matter jurisdiction over the case and is not an affirmative defense going to the merits of the case.[15]
Brown v. Parks, 173 Ga. 228, 160 S.E. 238 (1931); Georgia Power Co. v. Smith, 94 Ga. App. 166, 94 S.E.2d 48 (1956).

Trial court could impose on onion supplier the burden of producing records to prove its assertion that it had never owned the rotten onions, as negation of ownership was essential to supplier's defense. Williamson v. Strickland & Smith, Inc., 296 Ga. App. 1, 673 S.E.2d 858 (2009).
Mayo v. Owen, 208 Ga. 483, 67 S.E.2d 709 (1951); Hyer v. C.E. Holmes & Co., 12 Ga. App. 837, 79 S.E. 58 (1913); Phillips v. Lindsey, 31 Ga. App. 479, 120 S.E. 923 (1923).
Bellamy v. Georgia Power Co., 70 Ga. App. 175, 27 S.E.2d 783 (1943); Whitley v. Wilson, 90 Ga. App. 16, 81 S.E.2d 877 (1954); Carver v. Jones, 166 Ga. App. 197, 303 S.E.2d 529 (1983).
American Associated Companies v. Vaughan, 213 Ga. 119, 97 S.E.2d 144 (1957); Rinzler v. Westinghouse Elec. Corp., 103 Ga. App. 201, 119 S.E.2d 31 (1961).

Lewis v. Smith, 238 Ga. App. 6, 7, 517 S.E.2d 538 (1999) (citing Hodge v. SADA Enterprises, Inc., 217 Ga. App. 688, 691, 458 S.E.2d 876 (1995)); Miller v. Turner Broadcasting System, Inc., 339 Ga. App. 638, 794 S.E.2d 208 (2016).

When a motion for summary judgment is premised on the affirmative defense of assumption of risk, the defendants bear the burden of proof sufficient to establish that the plainfiff (1) had actual knowledge of the danger; (2) understood and appreciated the risks associated with such danger, and (3) voluntarily exposed himself to those risks. Fuller v. McCormick, 340 Ga. App. 636, 798 S.E.2d 280 (2017).
Franklin v. Eaves, 337 Ga. App. 292, 787 S.E.2d 265 (2016).
Hunter v. Sanders, 113 Ga. 140, 38 S.E. 406 (1901); Davison Chemical Corp. v. Hart, 68 Ga. App. 413, 23 S.E.2d 107 (1942); Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Thomas, 83 Ga. App. 477, 64 S.E.2d 301 (1951).
See the discussion in Metropolitan Publishers Representatives, Inc. v. Arnsdorff, 153 Ga. App. 877, 267 S.E.2d 260 (1980).

In pleading to a preceding pleading, a party shall set forth affirmatively accord and satisfaction, arbitration and award, discharge in bankruptcy, duress, estoppel, failure of consideration, fraud, illegality, injury by fellow servant, laches, license, payment, release, res judicata, statute of frauds, statute of limitations, and waiver. When a party has mistakenly designated a defense as a counterclaim or a counterclaim as a defense, the court on terms, if justice so requires, shall treat the pleadings as if there had been a proper designation.
Stewart v. Williams, 243 Ga. 580, 255 S.E.2d 699 (1979), held that proof of the reasonableness of an arrest was an affirmative defense in a false imprisonment action.
See Richards v. Southern Finance Corp., 171 Ga. App. 268, 319 S.E.2d 103 (1984) (failure of consideration is an affirmative defense).
Eidson v. Mathews, 120 Ga. App. 711, 172 S.E.2d 144 (1969).
Nash v. Hess Oil & Chemical Corp., 121 Ga. App. 546, 174 S.E.2d 373 (1970), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 226 Ga. 706, 177 S.E.2d 70 (1970).
Henry County Board of Education v. S.G., 301 Ga. 794, 804 S.E.2d 427, 347 Ed. Law Rep. 1232 (2017).
Lewis v. Smith, 238 Ga. App. 6, 7, 517 S.E.2d 538 (1999), “[A]n act of God is an affirmative defense upon which the defendant carries the burden of proof at trial and on summary judgment.”
Justification is an affirmative defense to a criminal charge. See Crane v. State, 281 Ga. 635, 641 S.E.2d 795 (2007); Berry v. State, 282 Ga. 376, 651 S.E.2d 1 (2007). See also O.C.G.A. § 16-3-21.

In a false imprisonment action, a police officer can assert an affirmative defense of “privilege” by showing that the person arrested was “sufficiently named” in the warrant and was “reasonably believed” to be person to be arrested. This essentially this amounts to a plea of justification. Stewart v. Williams, 243 Ga. 580, 255 S.E.2d 699 (1979). As to civil cases, see Bell v. Smith, 227 Ga. App. 17, 488 S.E.2d 91 (1997).
Coosa Valley Technical College v. West, 299 Ga. App. 171, 682 S.E.2d 187, 248 Ed. Law Rep. 934 (2009).
